div.l: For there biforn̄ he stale but curteisly
But thanne he was a thieff outragisly
For whiche the wardeyn chidde and mad fare
But þer of sette þe millere not a tare
He craked bost and swor it was not so
Thanne wer͗e ther͗e yonge pore scolers two
That dwelleden in þe halle of whiche y seye
Testiff they were and lusti for to pleye
And only for hir merthe and reuerie
Vp on the wardeyn besily they crie
To yeue hem leue but a litil stounde
To go to mille and se hir corn̄ y grounde
And hardely they durste leye hir nekke
The millere shuld not stele half a pekke
Of corn̄ ne be slegh ne force him be reue
And att laste þe wardeyn ȝaf him leue
Iohn hiȝt that on̄ and aleyn hiȝt þat othur
Off o toun̄ were þey bore that hiȝt strothur
Ferre in þe north y can not telle where
This alyen makyth redi all his gere
And on þe hors his saak he caste anon
Forth goth aleyn þe clerc and also Iohn
With good swerd and boker͗e by his side
Iohn knew þe wey him neded no gide
And att mille the sak a doun̄ alyȝt
Aleyn spak first al hayl symond in syȝt
How faire thy thy dowȝtur and thi wyff
Aleyn welcome ꝙquod symkyn bi my liff
And Iohn also how now what do ȝe here
Bi god symond ꝙquod Iohn nede has na pere
Him be houes to serue him self þᵗat has na swayn
Or ell he is a fole as clerkis sayn
Our͗e manciple I hope will be ded
Swa werkes ay the wanges in his hed
And therfor͗e am y come and eke aleyn
To grynde our͗e corn̄ and to carie hit ham ageyn
I pray you sped vs henne what ȝe may
Hit shall be don̄ ꝙquod symkyn by my fay
